questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a malodorous vaginal discharge that started a week earlier. On examination, the Whiff's test is positive, and the Gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. This infection is commonly treated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Methods

Amsel's Criteria

  • Presence of clue cells (more than 20% of the total cell population)
  • Positive whiff test
  • Vaginal pH greater than 4.5
  • Thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge
 

Microscopic Examination

  • Detection of clue cells in vaginal smear
 

Molecular Methods

  • Detection of ribosomal RNA of Gardnerella vaginalis using PCR

Treatment:

First-Line Treatment

  • Oral Metronidazole: 500 mg BD for 7 days
  • Tinidazole 2 g orally for 3 days

Alternative Treatment

  • Clindamycin 300 mg orally BD for 7 days

Acidic pH

Alkaline pH>7

Alkaline pH>7

Candidiasis

  • Dimorphic fungi
    • Blastospores (sacreoids)
    • Mycelia (invasion & adherence)
  • Curdy white discharge plaque on vaginal wall on removal causes petechiae
  • Out of proportion pruritus
  • Complicated/uncomplicated

Uncomplicated

  • Seen in normal women
  • Good prognosis
  • Associated with allicans

Complicated

  • In immunocompromised (in DM, TB, pregnancy etc)
  • Recurrent, severe
  • Associated with non-allicans

Treatment

  • Azoles
    • Oral
    • Fluconazole
    • Rx both male & female

Bacterial Vaginosis

  • Hemophilus vaginalis aka Garderella vaginalis
  • Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis require the presence of at least three out of the following five criteria

1. Presence of clue cells (>20%) on microscopic examination

2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5

3. Positive whiff test with KOH (fishy odor)

4. Thin, white homogeneous vaginal discharge

5. Fishy odour

Treatment

  • Metronidazole
  • Rx the women (no sexual transmission)

Trichomoniasis

  • By Trichomonas vaginalis flagellate protozoan
    • Motile organism causes severe irritation & severe pruritis
  • Colpitis Macularis (strawberry vagina)
  • Greenish yellow, frothy discharge

Treatment

  • Metronidazole
  • Rx both man & women

questions.text: A 29-year-old female complains of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A Giemsa stained smear of the discharge is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Bacterial Vaginosis

Candidiasis

Trichomoniasis

Causative agent

Overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and others

Candida albicans or other Candida species

Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan)

Discharge appearance

Thin, gray-white, homogeneous

Thick, white, "cottage cheese-like"

Yellow-green, frothy

Odor

Fishy (especially post-coital or with KOH)

None or mild

Foul-smelling

Vaginal pH

> 4.5

≤ 4.5

> 4.5

Whiff Test

Positive (fishy odor with KOH)

Negative

May be positive

Microscopy

Clue cells, few lactobacilli

Hyphae or pseudohyphae, spores

Motile trichomonads, many WBCs

Associated symptoms

Often asymptomatic, may have itching or irritation

Intense itching, burning, dyspareunia

Itching, burning, erythema

Treatment

Metronidazole or clindamycin

Fluconazole or topical antifungals

Metronidazole or tinidazole

questions.text: What are the potential long-term consequences of this condition in a 25-year-old female with a previous history of chlamydia infection who currently presents with mild fever, non-specific lower abdominal pain, mild diffuse tenderness upon deep palpation in the lower abdomen, cervical motion tenderness, and mucopurulent discharge from the vagina?
questions.explanation:
Pathogenesis

Infection ascends from the cervix and endometrium to the fallopian tubes and ovaries, causing inflammation and scarring. Can lead to infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and chronic pelvic pain.

Aetiology

Acute:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, E. coli, Mycoplasma genitalium, Anaerobes (Bacteroides species), Gardnerella vaginalis, Trichomonas vaginalis, Streptococci, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Actinomyces israelii.

 

Chronic: Same as acute, with possible additional mixed infections.

Clinical Features

Signs:

Fever, Purulent cervical discharge, Cervical motion tenderness, Adnexal tenderness, Abdominal tenderness.

 

Symptoms:

Lower abdominal pain, Abnormal vaginal discharge, Dyspareunia (pain during intercourse), Dysuria (pain during urination), Menstrual irregularities, Nausea and vomiting.

Complications
  • Infertility: Due to scarring and damage to fallopian tubes.
  • Ectopic Pregnancy
  • Chronic Pelvic Pain
  • Peritonitis
  • Sepsis

Laboratory Findings

Elevated WBC, Elevated CRP, Elevated ESR.

Ultrasound: Thickened, fluid-filled fallopian tubes and free pelvic fluid.

Next Step in Diagnosis

Endocervical Swab: Detects key pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae to guide treatment and prevent complications.

Treatment

First-line Therapy:

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose, or

Cefoxitin 2g IM single dose + Probenecid 1g PO single dose, or

Cefotaxime IV.

Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 14 days, with or without Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD for 14 days.

Male Partner Treatment

Treat with Cefixime + Azithromycin (Grey kit in India) to prevent reinfection.

Out-patient Therapy (India)

Yellow kit: Ceftriaxone, Doxycycline, Metronidazole for syndromic management.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT represent a characteristic feature of bacterial vaginosis?
questions.explanation:
Thin, gray-white discharge

Homogeneous vaginal discharge, often malodorous.

pH > 4.5

Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 is indicative.

Positive Whiff Test

Fishy odor when 10% KOH is added to the discharge.

Clue cells on microscopy

Vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, giving a stippled appearance.

Feature

BV

Normal

Colposcopic findings (A, B)

Homogeneous, milk-like secretions observed.

Homogeneous, clear secretions seen.

Microscopic findings (C, D)

Gardnerella-like microbes and presence of clue cells on microscopy.

Lactobacillus-like microbes observed with no clue cells.

Microbial composition

Overgrowth of anaerobes (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis).

Dominance of Lactobacillus species, maintaining vaginal acidity.

Clinical significance

Associated with fishy odor and elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), characteristic of BV.

Represents a healthy vaginal microbiome with stable pH (≤4.5) and protective lactobacilli.

Feature

Bacterial Vaginosis

Candidiasis

Trichomoniasis

Causative agent

Overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and others

Candida albicans or other Candida species

Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan)

Discharge appearance

Thin, gray-white, homogeneous

Thick, white, "cottage cheese-like"

Yellow-green, frothy

Odor

Fishy (especially post-coital or with KOH)

None or mild

Foul-smelling

Vaginal pH

> 4.5

≤ 4.5

> 4.5

Whiff Test

Positive (fishy odor with KOH)

Negative

May be positive

Microscopy

Clue cells, few lactobacilli

Hyphae or pseudohyphae, spores

Motile trichomonads, many WBCs

Associated symptoms

Often asymptomatic, may have itching or irritation

Intense itching, burning, dyspareunia

Itching, burning, erythema

Treatment

Metronidazole or clindamycin

Fluconazole or topical antifungals

Metronidazole or tinidazole

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram:

A patient came to the gynaecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, and intense itching. On examination, the cervix and vagina were spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism

What is the diagnosis of an 18-year-old girl who has been experiencing low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and amenorrhea for the past six months? During examination, a pelvic mass is detected on the left side, and signs of ascites are present
What is the etiologic agent responsible for causing granuloma inguinale
What is the causative organism responsible for vulval warts among the following options?

A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge?
A female patient having frothy vaginal discharge was found to have a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. The wet smear of the discharge is shown below. The drug of choice to treat this condition is _____
What is the likely diagnosis for the given image?
Kassowitz rule is related to:
Which of the following drugs cannot be given in bacterial vaginosis?
A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Microscopy revealed the cell shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
Identify the condition shown below?

A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perianal area. She also has complaints of difficulty in walking and sitting. She gives a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of inter-menstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause?

A 29-year-old woman presents with painless ulcers on the vulva; she gives a history of having multiple sexual partners. From the given options, what is the next best step to arrive at a diagnosis based on these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Non-treponemal tests

Treponemal-specific tests

  • VDRL test
  • RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test)
  • FTA-ABS
  • TP-PA
  • Both these tests measure IgM and IgG antibodies against cardiolipin.
  • False positives:
    • Recent vaccination
    • Febrile illness
    • Pregnancy
    • IV drug abusers
    • SLE
    • Ageing
    • Cancer

They remain positive for life after the infection.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the lowest occurrence of perinatal transmission?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

It is an RNA togavirus

Transmission

Nasopharyngeal secretions

Maternal features

  • Mild febrile illness
  • Generalized maculopapular lesion beginning on the face and then spreading to the trunk and extremities
  • Arthralgia or arthritis
  • Head and neck lymphadenopathy
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Spontaneous abortions
  • Devastating fetal infections

Fetal features

  • 13 to 14 gestation: 50% incidence of an affected fetus
  • End of 2nd trimester: 25%
  • After 20 weeks: Defects are rare

Diagnosis

  • Urine analysis
  • Blood analysis
  • Nasopharyngeal secretions
  • CSF analysis
  • ELISA: Specific IgM antibody

Management and prevention

  • Droplet precautions for 7 days after onset of rash
  • Postexposure passive immunization with IVIG within 5 days of exposure
  • MMR vaccine to non-pregnant women of childbearing age
  • Targeted USG to determine fetal anomalies in infected mothers
  • Vaccination of all susceptible hospital personnel

questions.text: What are clue cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaginal epithelial cells lined by bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: Cervical epithelial cells lined by bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: Uterine endothelial cells lined by bacteria

questions.correct_answer: A. Vaginal epithelial cells lined by bacteria
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Vaginal epith

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of severe vaginal irritation and pruritus. On examination, you note a greenish-yellow, frothy discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Trichomonas vaginalis vaginitis

Candida albicans vaginitis (Moniliasis)

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)

pH

≥ 4.5

< 4.5

≥ 4.5

Other Symptoms

Itching and irritation in and around vaginal opening, dysuria

Intense vulvovaginal pruritus (out of proportion to the discharge), splash dysuria, dyspareunia

Generally not accompanied by itching or inflammation but may be associated with complications such as PID and pregnancy complications

Diagnosis

Motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy

Identification of mycelia, pseudohyphae, and spores by direct smear and staining (methylene blue)

Amsel's four diagnostic criteria (three of four are sufficient): (1) Homogenous vaginal discharge, (2) Vaginal pH > 4.5, (3) Positive whiff test, (4) Clue cells

Microscopy

Motile, pear-shaped, flagellated organisms

Hyphae and buds, spores

 

 

Clue cells (>20% of cells)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist complaining of curd-like white vaginal discharge. Upon examination, the physician observes that when attempting to remove the discharge, petechiae are seen. What condition is most likely causing these findings?
questions.explanation:
Vaginal Candidiasis

Risk Factors

Risk factors for developing this infection include:

  • Diabetes
  • Pregnancy
  • Use of broad-spectrum antibiotics
  • Use of combined oral contraceptive pills
  • Immunosuppression and steroid use

 

Clinical features
  • Vaginal discharge
  • Intense itching of the vulva and vagina
  • Pain during intercourse (dyspareunia) due to soreness

Examination Findings
  • A thick, white, curd-like discharge
  • Pelvic examination may be tender, and removing the white discharge can reveal multiple sore spots

 

Diagnosis
  • On KOH mount, the filamentous form of mycelia and pseudohyphae of the fungus can be seen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman from an endemic area presents with chronic pelvic pain, irregular menstrual cycles, and primary infertility. She has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis treated 5 years ago. Her gynecologist suspects genital tuberculosis and is discussing the pattern of organ involvement with medical students. Most common organ infected with genital tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B. Fallopian tu
